details: The Yaogan 32-02-01 and 32-02-02 are Chinese military satellites of unknown purpose.
Progress (in Russian: "Прогресс") MS-18 is a Russian cargo vehicle which will resupply the International Space Station. This will be the 171st flight of a Progress.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Jilin 1 satellites are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites for high-definition video within the Jilin-1 constellation designed and owned by the Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co.
Flight F44.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA255.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: No Details

location: LC-2, Naro Space Center, South Korea
details: First flight of KSLV-2. First flight of an entirely South Korean launcher.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Lucy is a NASA space probe that will tour five Jupiter trojans, asteroids that share Jupiter's orbit around the Sun, orbiting either ahead of or behind the planet. All will be fly-by missions. Three instruments comprise the payload: a high-resolution visible imager, an optical and near-infrared imaging spectrometer, and a thermal infrared spectrometer.

location: Site 901 (SLS-1), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Shenzhou 13 (Chinese: 神舟十三号) was a Chinese spaceflight launched on 15 October 2021 at 16:23 UTC. The flight marked the eighth crewed Chinese spaceflight and the thirteenth flight of the Shenzhou program. The spacecraft carried three People's Liberation Army Astronaut Corps (PLAAC) taikonauts on the second flight to the Tianhe core module, the first module of the Tiangong space station. The launch of the three-person crew with a Long March-2F launch vehicle took place from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Chinese Hα Solar Explorer (CHASE) is designed to test a newly developed satellite platform and conduct solar observations. The scientific payload of the satellite is an Hα imaging spectrograph (HIS), which can, for the first time, acquire full-disk spectroscopic solar observations in the Hα waveband.
Flight ST-36.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: Chris Boshuizen, Glen de Vries, William Shatner, and Audrey Powers flew aboard New Shepard. William Shatner became the oldest person to date to travel into space, at 90 years old.

Soyuz MS-19 is a crewed mission to the International Space Station.
The crew is composed by the cosmonaut and mission commander Anton Shkaplerov and 2 tourists: Klim Shipenko and Yulia Peresild. They will use the time aboard the ISS to shoot some scenes of a movie called "The Challenge".

Landsat 9 is an American Earth observation satellite. NASA is in charge of building, launching, and testing the system, while the United States Geological Survey (USGS) will process, archive, and distribute its data. It's intended as the eighth satellite in the Landsat series, Landsat 6 failed to reach orbit.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The satellite suffered an anomaly during launch, but was rumoured - and subsequently observed via orbital changes - to have been recovered about a month after launch.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The rocket is named "Peace Elite", from a Chinese video game, which sponsors this launch. The usernames of the players of the game will also be launched on this flight.

location: LC-201, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: The Tianzhou (Chinese: 天舟; lit. 'Heavenly Ship') is a Chinese automated cargo spacecraft developed from China's first prototype space station Tiangong-1 to resupply its modular space station. It was first launched (Tianzhou 1) on the Long March 7 rocket on April 20, 2017, and demonstrated autonomous propellant transfer (space refueling).

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: Inspiration4 is the world’s first all-civilian mission to space, and the second fully private crewed spaceflight, after Soyuz TM-30 in 2000. The mission will be commanded by Jared Isaacman, the 37-year-old founder and Chief Executive Officer of Shift4 Payments and an accomplished pilot and adventurer. Inspiration4 will leave Earth from Kennedy Space Center’s historic Launch Complex 39A, the embarkation point for Apollo and Space Shuttle missions, and travel across a low earth orbit on a multi-day journey that will continually eclipse more than 90% of the earth’s population. Named in recognition of the four-person crew that will raise awareness and funds for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, this milestone represents a new era for human spaceflight and exploration, according to the company.
Flight ST-35.
First launch of Starlink satellites from Vandenberg SFB, and first launch to the second orbital shell.
Unconfirmed payload.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Zhongxing-9B is a Chinese communications satellite, that will replace the Zhongxing-9A satellite in orbit. The latter was launched in 2017, but the CZ-3B launch vehicle suffered a partial failure, and the satellite had to burn a large amount of fuel to reach its nominal orbit.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Gaofen (GF) is a series of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites for the state-sponsored program China High-definition Earth Observation System (CHEOS).
The first flight of Firefly Alpha.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: First booster landing on A Shortfall of Gravitas, SpaceX's newest droneship. First reuse of a Cargo Dragon 2 capsule.

location: LP-3B, Pacific Spaceport Complex, Kodiak, Alaska, USA
details: LV0006. First launch of Rocket 3 with a customer payload. First Rocket 3 with stretched propellant tanks.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: New Shepard flew a NASA lunar landing technology demonstration for a second time on the exterior of the booster, 18 commercial payloads inside the crew capsule, 11 of which are NASA-supported, and an art installation on the exterior of the capsule.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: TJSW-7 is likely a Chinese early warning satellite.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: "Ronghe Shiyan Weixing" (RSW) = "Integrated Experimental Satellite" are test satellites that will be used to develop a state-owned Chinese low-earth orbit constellation, Xingwang, consisting of several thousand satellites.
Flight ST-34.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: TH 2 (Tianhui-2 = "Sky drawing") is a Chinese series of cartography and Earth observation satellites.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV-19.

location: Second Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: 3rd stage suffered insufficient pressure in the liquid hydrogen tank at engine start, due to vent and relief valve soft seal damage and leakage, which led to a failed engine ignition.

location: LP-0A, Wallops Flight Facility, Virginia, USA
details: Cygnus NG-16 (Northrop Grumman-16) is a cargo resupply mission of the Northrop Grumman Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station under the Commercial Resupply Services (CRS) contract with NASA.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Chinese communication satellite. It would provide Ku-band communications and feature advanced multiple steerable spot beam antenna technology to allow ground users to communicate while traveling, as well as secure uplink transmission for satellite antenna control.

location: LC-16, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details:
The KL-Beta A and B, satellites are test satellites for a global multimedia satellite system for the German company KLEO Connect.
The satellites were built by CAS Microspace and feature a Ka-band communications payload.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Payload fairing failed to separate, due to the silicone rubber fitting stuck on the separation bolt access covers along the longitudinal separation plane.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA-254.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details:
Monolith is a USAF Research Laboratory technology demonstration satellite.
The microsatellite is set to demonstrate new deployable instruments in very small satellite bus. Monolith will carry a weather monitoring instrument.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Tianhui 1 (TH-1) is a stereo-topographic mapping satellite developed by China SpaceSat Co. Ltd., a commercial branch of China Academy of Space Technology (CAST), with the development commencing in 2005. The satellite is similar in roles and capability to Ziyuan 3 but features a different electro-optical mission payload developed by the Changchun Institute of Optics, Fine Machinery, and Physics (CIOMP) of the China Academy of Sciences (CAS).
First new module of the ISS since 2016 (BEAM). First flight of Proton-M without an upper stage.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: First time New Shepard launched astronauts to space.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Payload identity not confirmed.

location: VMS Eve, Spaceport America, New Mexico, USA
details: First fully crewed flight for SpaceShipTwo.

location: LC-16, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Ningxin-1 satellites (also called Zhongzi) are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites owned by Ningxia Jingui Information Technology Co. Ltd.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Tianlian 1, also known as Tian Lian 1, TL-1, and CTDRS-1 is a Chinese data tracking and relay communications satellite series. Based on the DFH-3 satellite bus, it will provide communication coverage for manned Shenzhou missions, from Shenzhou 7 onwards. Functionally, it is similar to the United States Tracking and Data Relay Satellite System.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The newer FY-3 series is an improved generation of polar-orbiting heliosynchronous weather satellites.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Jilin 1 satellites are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites for high-definition video within the Jilin-1 constellation designed and owned by the Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co.
Flight ST-33.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Transporter 2 is a dedicated rideshare mission by SpaceX. SpaceX’s SmallSat Rideshare Program provides small satellite operators with regularly scheduled, dedicated Falcon 9 rideshare missions to SSO for ESPA class payloads for as low as $1 million per mission, which includes up to 200 kg of payload mass.

location: Cosmic Girl, Mojave Air and Space Port, California, USA
details:
The Space Test Program (STP) is the primary provider of spaceflight for the United States Department of Defense (DoD) space science and technology community. STP is conducted by the Advanced Systems and Development Directorate, a directorate of the Space and Missile Systems Center of the United States Air Force.
Missions part of STP-27VPA:
- HALO-Net Free Flyer: is a 3U CubeSat with the main aim to test a retroreflectors array and to validate predicting models.
- Gunsmoke-J 4: is an experimental 3U CubeSat to test direct communications to Army combat operations.
- CNCE Blk.1 (1 and 3): are experimental CubeSats used to test advanced satellite-satellite communication.
Progress (in Russian: "Прогресс") MS-17 is a Russian cargo vehicle which will resupply the International Space Station. This will be the 169th flight of a Progress.
Payload identity unconfirmed.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Yaogan-30 09 are a triplet of Chinese satellites of the Yaogan constellation. The purpose is not confirmed, although the news reports hint towards a SIGINT mission, especially to detect ships by their radio emissions. They are launched by triplet, in a similar way to the old American NOSS system, or to the Yaogan-31 constellation.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: GPS III (Global Positioning System) is the first evolution of the third generation of GPS satellites. The U.S. Air Force announced in May 2008 that a team led by Lockheed Martin had won the competition to build the next-generation Global Positioning System (Navstar) Space System program, known as GPS III.

location: Site 901 (SLS-1), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First Shenzhou flight since 2016. First crewed flight to the new Chinese modular space station.

location: LP-0B, Wallops Flight Facility, Virginia, USA
details: NROL-111 is a classified mission for the National Reconnoissance Office.

Odyssey (TacRL-2) is a space domain awareness satellite that was procured under the Space Force's responsive launch program. The spacecraft was built in under a year and the launch provider was given three weeks of notice for the launch.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: 0.5 m resolution Earth observation satellite for Twenty First Century Aerospace Technology Company Ltd.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SXM-8 is the ninth high-powered, digital, audio radio satellite built by Maxar (SSL) for SiriusXM. Built on Maxar’s 1300-class platform and designed to provide more than 15 years of service, SXM-8 is more than 8 meters tall and weighed nearly 7,000 kg at launch. SXM-8 has a large, mesh, unfurlable reflector almost 10 meters in diameter that allows SiriusXM programming to reach its radios, including those in moving vehicles.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX CRS-22, also known as SpX-22, was a Commercial Resupply Service mission to the International Space Station. Dragon was docked to the station for 35 days before it successfully returned to Earth. 3,328kg of cargo were brought to the station, including the first of three pairs of iROSA solar arrays which will provide additional power to the station.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Fengyun, abbreviated FY, are China's weather satellites. China has launched polar orbit and geosynchronous orbit meteorological satellites since 1988. The satellites in the FY-1 and FY-3 series are polar-orbiting sun-synchronous orbits. The satellites in the FY-2 and FY-4 series are in geosynchronous orbit.

location: LC-201, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: First cargo flight to the new Chinese space station.
Flight ST-32.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Final launch of the first shell of Starlink satellites.

location: VMS Eve, Spaceport America, New Mexico, USA
details: The flight incorporated all of the original test objectives from the previous test flight which was aborted early, including evaluating elements of the customer cabin, testing the live stream capability from the spaceship to the ground, and assessing the upgraded horizontal stabilizers and flight controls during the boost phase of the flight.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: 400th Chinese orbital flight.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The Space-Based Infrared System (SBIRS) is a consolidated system intended to meet the United States' infrared space surveillance needs through the first two to three decades of the 21st century. The SBIRS program is designed to provide key capabilities in the areas of missile warning, missile defense and battlespace characterization via satellites in geosynchronous earth orbit (GEO), sensors hosted on satellites in highly elliptical orbit (HEO), and ground-based data processing and control. SBIRS ground software integrates infrared sensor programs of the U.S. Air Force (USAF) with new IR sensors.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: 2nd stage Thrust Vector Control (TVC) system failed just after engine ignition due to engine igniter operations causing corruption of signals within the engine computer.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: First time a Falcon 9 booster flew for a 10th time, successfully completing the goal to fly a booster 10 times without significant refurbishment. Additionally, this is the fastest turnaround of droneship JRTI to date, at 10 days and 3 hours, beating its previous record by over 2 days.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The purpose of the satellites is not confirmed, although the news reports hint towards a SIGINT mission, especially to detect ships by their radio emissions. They are also known as CX 5 by the manufacturer. They are launched by triplet, in a similar way to the old American NOSS system, or to the Yaogan-31 constellation.

location: Suborbital Pad A, Starbase, Texas, USA
details: First successful landing of a Starship prototype. Although one of the 3 Raptor engines shut down early on ascent and was not able to relight, SN15 was still able to achieve a soft landing.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Yaogan 34 is an optical remote sensing satellite, with a ground image resolution of a few meters, mainly used for land census, urban planning, land rights, road network design, crop yield estimation, and disaster prevention and mitigation. It was built by SAST.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX will launch a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: LC-101, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: First module of the new Chinese space station. Third Chinese space station, and the first modular space station to be launched this century.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV-18. Return to flight for Vega after the VV17 failure.

location: LC-16, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Qilu-1 is a synthetic aperture radar (SAR) remote sensing satellite and Qilu-4 is an optical remote sensing satellite, and both operate in the X-band for measurement and control data transmission.

The KH-11 series, known as Kennen and Crystal, are American spy satellites utilizing electro-optical digital imaging for real-time observation, supplanting earlier film-return satellites. Manufactured by Lockheed, they likely incorporate a 2.4 m prime mirror, offering a theoretical 15 cm ground resolution. First launched by the American National Reconnaissance Office in December 1976, the KH-11 KENNEN was the inaugural American spy satellite to employ electro-optical digital imaging technology, enabling real-time optical observations.
Flight ST-31.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: First SpaceX crewed mission to feature a flight-proven booster and the first SpaceX crewed mission to feature a flight-proven Dragon spacecraft. Crew Dragon Endeavour previously flew on the SpaceX Demo-2 mission.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: The NS-15 was an uncrewed test flight to verify that the launch vehicle and capsule are ready for crewed spaceflight. Before and after the launch, a crew boarded the spacecraft to simulate events that would occur during a real crewed flight.

Soyuz MS-18 is a crewed mission to the International Space Station. It will feature two Russian Cosmonauts, Oleg Novitsky, Petr Dubrov, and NASA Astronaut Mark Vande Hei for the launch. It will return home with cosmonaut Oleg Novitsky, film director Klim Shipenko, and an actress who will be completing a movie mission.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: No Details

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Gaofen (GF) is a series of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites for the state-sponsored program China High-definition Earth Observation System (CHEOS).

location: Suborbital Pad B, Starbase, Texas, USA
details: SN11 was destroyed shortly after engine relight due to a hard start on engine 2.
Flight ST-30.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: Gunsmoke-J, formerly named Jacob's Ladder, is an experimental 3U CubeSat designed by the US Army Space Missile Defense Command to demonstrate advanced information collection in direct support of the Army combat operations.
First launch fully commercialized by GK Launch Services. First Catalan and Tunisian satellite to be launched. First white Soyuz to be launched since IRS-1B in 1991.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: First time a Falcon 9 booster flew for a 9th time.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Yaogan-31 satellites are Chinese military satellites, launched in triplets, similar to the American NOSS system. They are equipped with two solar panels each. This constellation is used for ELINT (Electronic Intelligence). The Yaogan-31 satellites are also followed on their orbit by the Yaogan-34 observation satellites, used to confirm or complete the observation made by the Yaogan-31 triplet.

location: LC-201, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: Unknown satellite purported for "new technology validation".

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.

location: Suborbital Pad A, Starbase, Texas, USA
details: SN10 successfully completed a 10-kilometer test flight with the first ever successful flip maneuver and landing, however, it landed hard due to helium bubbles being ingested by the landing engine. As a result, SN10 landed hard and exploded a few minutes later.

Arktika (Russian: Арктика) is a constellation of satellites being developed by Russia with the aim of providing better satellite coverage for the Arctic territories in the field of telecommunications, meteorology and navigation. The objective is to support the economic development of these regions. Indeed, Russia has vast territories above the Arctic Circle that are poorly served by satellites optimized to cover lower latitudes.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: Flight C51.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Yaogan-31 satellites are Chinese military satellites, launched in triplets, similar to the American NOSS system. They are equipped with two solar panels each. This constellation is used for ELINT (Electronic Intelligence). The Yaogan-31 satellites are also followed on their orbit by the Yaogan-34 observation satellites, used to confirm or complete the observation made by the Yaogan-31 triplet.

location: LP-0A, Wallops Flight Facility, Virginia, USA
details: Cygnus NG-15 (Northrop Grumman-15) is a cargo resupply mission of the Northrop Grumman Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station under the Commercial Resupply Services contract with NASA.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX launched a batch of Starlink satellites for their high-speed low earth orbit internet constellation.
At the end of its mission, Progress MS-16 will remove the Pirs module from the station.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: TJS 6 (Tongxin Jishu Shiyan) is a Chinese geostationary satellite.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX unexpectedly changed the booster assignment from B1059 to B1060, making this the fastest turnaround to date, at 27 days, and the first time a Falcon 9 flew twice within a month.
The payload identity, although very likely, has not been officially announced.

location: Suborbital Pad B, Starbase, Texas, USA
details: SN9 failed to reignite one of its engines for its landing burn and failed to land.

location: Safir Launch Pad, Semnan Space Center, Iran
details: First flight of Zoljanah. On this flight, only the first two stages were active.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First operational launch of Hyperbola-1.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Yaogan-31 satellites are Chinese military satellites, launched in triplets, similar to the American NOSS system. They are equipped with two solar panels each. This constellation is used for ELINT (Electronic Intelligence). The Yaogan-31 satellites are also followed on their orbit by the Yaogan-34 observation satellites, used to confirm or complete the observation made by the Yaogan-31 triplet.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Transporter 1 is a dedicated rideshare mission by SpaceX. SpaceX’s SmallSat Rideshare Program provides small satellite operators with regularly scheduled, dedicated Falcon 9 rideshare missions to SSO for ESPA class payloads for as low as $1 million per mission, which includes up to 200 kg of payload mass.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: First Falcon 9 to fly for an 8th time, and fastest booster turnaround to date at 38 days. Additionally, this was the fastest turnaround of droneship JRTI to date, at 12 days and 11 hours, beating its previous record by almost 8 days.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The mission will launch a single communication microsatellite for OHB Group that will enable specific frequencies to support future services from orbit. The launch will be Rocket Lab’s 18th Electron mission and was procured for OHB Group through OHB Cosmos International Launch Service GmbH, the launch service division of OHB Group. OHB Cosmos is responsible for launching the spacecraft built by the Group's satellite manufacturers based in Germany, Sweden, and the Czech Republic.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Designed by the CAST Institute (China Academy of Space Technology), a subsidiary of the Chinese aerospace group CASC specializing in spacecraft design, the Tiantong-1 02 satellite will be operated by China Satellite Communications Co. Ltd, another CASC subsidiary that owns about ten communication satellites such as the ChinaStar and APStar.

location: Cosmic Girl, Mojave Air and Space Port, California, USA
details: The CACTUS 1 (Coordinated Applied Capitol Technology University Satellite 1) is a 3U CubeSat mission developed at the Capitol Technology University to demonstrate new technologies for nanosatellites.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: First Flight of New Shepard 4 (NS4)

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Türksat 5A is a telecommunications satellite operated by the state-owned Türksat A.Ş.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS25. First launch for the French Air and Space Force.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Chinese Yaogan 33R (Remote Sensing Satellite-33R) government remote sensing satellite, likely also used as a military reconnaissance satellite, is likely the first of a successor series to the Yaogan-1 (JB-5) class space-based synthetic aperture radar (SAR) system.

location: LC-201, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: First flight of Long March 8.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: Classified payload for the National Reconnaissance Office. The identity and purpose of the satellite are not known.
First French launch (Arianespace/Starsem) from the Vostochnyi cosmodrome. Flight ST-29.

location: Second Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: CMS-01 (previously named GSAT-12R) is a geostationary communications satellite built by ISRO. It will replace GSAT-12 at the 83°E position, colocated with Insat-2E and Insat-4A with a mission life of 7 years. The bus system is based on I-1K (I-1000) platform with ASIC-based BMU and 64 Ah Li-ion batteries.

location: LP-3B, Pacific Spaceport Complex, Kodiak, Alaska, USA
details: Second demonstration flight of the Rocket 3 launcher. Rocket 3.2 had a successful first-stage ascent and second-stage ignition. However, the final velocity was just short of orbit, due to a poor mixing ratio of second-stage propellants.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The StriX-α satellite was too large to fit in a conventional fairing, so Electron used a modified one on this flight, with 4 extensions on the sides.
First flight of Angara since 2014.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: First reuse of fairings on a commercial launch. One of Falcon 9's fairing halves previously flew on the ANASIS-II mission.

location: VMS Eve, Spaceport America, New Mexico, USA
details: The plane's engine was shut down about 1 second after its ignition due to a computer communications issue. The vehicle was able to return and land on the runway.

location: SLC-37B, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: NROL-44 is a classified payload for the National Reconnaissance Office. While no payload has been confirmed, it is likely an Orion Reconnaissance Satellite.

location: Suborbital Pad A, Starbase, Texas, USA
details: First flight of a full-scale Starship prototype. SN8 landed hard and was destroyed due to low pressure in the liquid methane header tank, however most test objectives were achieved.

location: Mobile Launcher Pad, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First flight of a CZ-11 made in Haiyang, instead of Xi'an.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: The first mission of SpaceX's second Commercial Resupply Services contract with NASA. The first flight of the Dragon 2 cargo version.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First flight of the CZ-3B/G5 variant. First CZ-3 flight to SSO.

Goniets is a Russian civilian low Earth orbit communication satellite system. It consists of a number of satellites, derived from Strela military communication satellites. Goniets-M are upgraded versions of the Goniets satellites, a civilian derivate of the military Strela-3 satellite system. They are operated in the Goniets-D1M constellation.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS24.

JDRS 1 is a Japanese data relay satellite with a dual military and civil mission. The satellite was built by Mitsubishi Electric (MELCO), probably using their DS-2000 bus. The military payload is an optical data relay payload to connect with the latest generation IGS-Optical and IGS-Radar reconnaissance satellites.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: 100th Launch of the Falcon 9. First ever 7th-flight of a Falcon 9 booster.

location: LC-101, Wenchang Space Launch Site, China
details: First Lunar sample-return mission since Luna 24 in 1976. China will become the third country to retrieve lunar surface samples back to Earth, after the USA and the Soviet Union.
Sentinel-6A aims to continue high-precision ocean altimetry measurements in the 2020–2030 time-frame using two successive, identical satellites, Jason-CS-A and Jason-CS-B.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: First attempt to recover an Electron first stage. Recovery did not use a helicopter, and instead splashed down and was recovered via Rocket Lab's recovery ship named Catch of the Day.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV17. AVUM 4th stage lost attitude control during burn due to wrongly connected electrical wiring of electro-mechanical actuators controls for the 4th stage Thrust Vector Control (TVC) system. Both payloads re-entered the atmosphere before making a complete orbit.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX's first operational mission as part of NASA's Commercial Crew Program. The first flight of Dragon Resilience. First flight of a non-American astronaut on Crew Dragon.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The first Atlas V to use GEM-63 solid rocket boosters.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Designed by the CAST Institute (China Academy of Space Technology), a subsidiary of the Chinese aerospace group CASC specializing in spacecraft design, the Tiantong-1 02 satellite will be operated by China Satellite Communications Co. Ltd, another CASC subsidiary that owns about ten communication satellites such as the ChinaStar and APStar.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: EOS-1 (Radar Imaging Satellite) are satellite imaging missions of ISRO using an active SAR (Synthetic Aperture Radar) imager to provide continuity of service for RISAT-2. The objective of the RISAT mission is to use the all-weather as well as the day-and-night SAR observation capability in applications such as agriculture, forestry, soil moisture, geology, sea ice, coastal monitoring, object identification, and flood monitoring, but also for military surveillance.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First flight of Ceres-1. Mission name "I Believe I Can Fly".

location: LC-16, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Satellogic is the first Argentine company to have realized nanosatellites. It is currently setting up a constellation called Aleph-1, which will initially consist of 25 "ÑuSat" satellites. It is a 90-satellite constellation, working as a scalable Earth observation platform with the ability to weekly remap the entire planet at high resolution to provide affordable geospatial insights for daily decision-making.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: GPS III (Global Positioning System) is the first evolution of the third generation of GPS satellites. The U.S. Air Force announced in May 2008 that a team led by Lockheed Martin had won the competition to build the next-generation Global Positioning System (Navstar) Space System program, known as GPS III.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The Flock earth observing constellation made and operated by Planet Labs consists of numerous triple CubeSats. The majority of the satellites featured a standard RGB imaging system, but five satellites were fitted with experimental systems working in different optical spectral bands.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Yaogan-30 07 is a triplet of Chinese satellites of the Yaogan constellation. The purpose is not confirmed, although the news reports hint towards a SIGINT mission, especially to detect ships by their radio emissions. They are launched in triplets, in a similar way to the old American NOSS system, or to the Yaogan-31 constellation.

GLONASS-K (Russian: Глобальная навигационная спутниковая система, "Global Navigation Satellite System") is the latest satellite design intended as a part of the Russian GLONASS radio-based satellite navigation system. Developed by ISS Reshetnev (Information Satellite Systems Reshetnev) and first launched on 26 February 2011, it is a substantial improvement of the previous GLONASS-M second-generation satellites, having a longer lifespan and better accuracy.

As a first mission, this small network of miniature CubeSats will attempt to resolve current densities at varying spatial resolutions in the near-Earth magnetosphere using measurements from Anisotropic Resistance Magnetometers."

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: HaiYang (Chinese: "Ocean"), abbreviated HY, is a marine remote sensing satellite series planned by China. The 442 kg box-shaped satellite is three-axis-stabilized and Earth-oriented, with the twin solar wings oriented to the sun. It incorporates an integrated onboard operation management system and has a design life of five years. Its payloads include a 10-band ocean color scanner with a revisit period of 3 days and a 4-band CCD imager with a revisit period of 7 days.

The Jilin-1 High Resolution 02 satellites feature an imaging system with a resolution of 0.75 m in panchromatic mode, better than 3 m in multispectral mode, and an image swath of 40 km from a 535 km high orbit. The satellites operate in push-broom mode and are capable of imaging up to 45° off-track.

As part of a first stage block upgrade, Electron’s booster will include guidance and navigation hardware, including S-band telemetry and onboard flight computer systems, to gather data during the first stage’s atmospheric re-entry. The stage is also equipped with a reaction control system to orient the booster during its re-entry descent.

location: Stargazer, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The Ionospheric Connection Explorer (ICON) is a satellite designed to investigate changes in the Earth's ionosphere. ICON will study the interaction between Earth's weather systems and space weather driven by the Sun, and how this interaction drives turbulence in the upper atmosphere. It is hoped that a better understanding of this dynamic will mitigate its effects on communications, GPS signals, and technology in general.

Eutelsat Communications has selected in October 2016 Airbus Defence and Space and Orbital ATK, now Northrop Grumman Innovation Systems (NGIS), to build a new satellite for the key 5° West orbital position serving mainly video markets in Europe and North Africa.

It is the follow-on version of the ZY-1 02C satellite. The primary objective is to acquire high-resolution panchromatic and multispectral imagery for land resource surveys, disaster monitoring, forestry, and ecological monitoring.

details: Taizhi 1 or KS 09 is a Chinese small satellite built by DFH Satellite Co. to test technologies for a future gravitational wave detector mission.

The Geo-IK-2 is a Russian series of new generation military geodesy satellites replacing the Soviet Union's Geo-IK and Sfera constellations. They are intended to be used to create high precision three-dimensional maps of the Earth's surface, and to monitor plate tectonics. The satellites are produced by ISS Reshetnev, and have a mass of around 1,400 kilograms. They operate in a circular orbit at an altitude of around 1,000 kilometres above the Earth's surface.

Soyuz MS-14 will carry no crew members, as it is intended to test a modification of the launch abort system for integration with the Soyuz-2.1a launch vehicle. Unlike the traditional Soyuz-FG launcher which is turned on the launch pad to set the azimuth of its flight, Soyuz-2 performs a roll maneuver during its flight to change direction. The maneuver may trigger the analog launch abort system designed for Soyuz-FG. Soyuz MS-14 will test a solution for this issue.
Soyuz MS-14 attempted to dock at ISS's Poisk module, but emergency abort was triggered. Soyuz MS-13, piloted by Aleksandr Skvortsov, will be moved to the Poisk module, Soyuz MS-14 will dock with the Zvezda module.

Spektr-RG (Russian for Spectrum + Röntgen + Gamma; also called Spectrum-X-Gamma, SRG, SXG) is an international high-energy astrophysics observatory, which is being built under the leadership of the Russian Space Research Institute (IKI). Spektr-RG instrumentation includes 5 telescopes spanning the energy range from the far ultraviolet to the hard X-ray, plus an all-sky monitor.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: 2nd stage motor failed due to thermal failure/burn-through at the motor's forward dome, leading to a loss of the launch vehicle and its payload. Flight VV15.
The launch wasn't announced in advance.
Meteor-M No.2-2 is a Russian meteorological satellite.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: BlackSky Global 3 is the third of sixty high resolution earth observation microsatellites in the BlackSky constellation. This constellation will provide real-time earth observation. the constellation is built by Blacksky, a SpaceFlight Subsidiary, and the satellites are produced by LeoStella LLC, a joint venture of Spaceflight Industries and Thales Alenia Space.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: With four burns of the second stage, STP-2 was SpaceX's most complicated mission yet.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. When fully completed, BeiDou will provide an alternative global navigation satellite system to the United States-owned Global Positioning System (GPS) and is expected to be more accurate than the GPS. It was claimed in 2016 that BeiDou-3 will reach millimeter-level accuracy (with post-processing), which is ten times more accurate than the finest level of GPS.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA248.
Most valuable commercial payload put into orbit to date.

location: Tai Rui Barge (Area 1), China Coastal Waters
details:
First sea launch of Long March 11.
China becomes the third country to launch rockets from the ocean, after Italy (Scout) and Russia/USSR (Zenit, Shtil, and Volna).

Yamal 601 is a geostationary communications satellite ordered by Gazprom Space Systems to ISS Reshetnev on the Ekspress-2000 platform for its Yamal program. The Ekspress-2000 platform can generate up to 14 kW of power on an unpressurized bus designed for direct GEO injection with 15 years of design life. Its payload will be supplied by Thales Alenia Space and is composed of 18 C band, 19 Ku band and 26 Ka band transponders for a 36 MHz equivalent of 52 transponders. It will replace Yamal 202 on 49°E.

1900th launch of a Soyuz.
The rocket was struck by lightning shortly after liftoff, but the vehicle was able to get into orbit without a problem.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: First dedicated Starlink mission and the heaviest payload mass launched to date by SpaceX.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The launch failed due to a technical problem with the third stage.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: RISAT (Radar Imaging Satellite) is a series of Indian radar imaging reconnaissance satellites built by ISRO. They provide all-weather surveillance using synthetic aperture radars (SAR).

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-2 (formerly known as COMPASS) is a constellation of navigation satellites. It is not an extension of the older BeiDou-1 but rather supersedes it outright. The new system will be a constellation of 35 satellites, which include 5 geostationary orbit satellites for backward compatibility with BeiDou-1, and 30 non-geostationary satellites (27 in medium Earth orbit and 3 in inclined geosynchronous orbit), that will offer complete coverage of the globe.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The mission has been procured by the DoD Space Test Program in partnership with Defense Innovation Unit (DIU) as part of its Rapid Agile Launch Initiative. The three experiments on board will demonstrate advanced space technologies and accelerate the fielding of future operational space capabilities.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX CRS-17, also known as SpX-17, was a Commercial Resupply Service mission to the International Space Station. Dragon was berthed to the station for 27 days before it successfully returned to Earth. 2,482kg of cargo were brought to the station, 1,517kg pressurized, 965kg unpressurized.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: The mission flew 38 payloads for a variety of schools, universities, government agencies, and private companies.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: TH 2 (Tianhui-2 = "Sky drawing") is a Chinese series of earth observation satellites.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. It was claimed in 2016 that BeiDou-3 will reach millimeter-level accuracy (with post-processing), which is ten times more accurate than the finest level of GPS.

location: LP-0A, Wallops Flight Facility, Virginia, USA
details: Last flight of Antares 230.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: This was the first time that a Falcon Heavy was used for a commercial launch.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS22.
Progress MS-11 is a Soviet/Russian Progress cargo vehicle which docked to the ISS. It's the 163rd Progress flight.

location: Second Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: The first flight of PSLV in the QL configuration featuring four solid rocket boosters.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The TL 2 (Tian Lian 2) satellite is a geostationary relay satellite based on the DFH-4 Bus (three-axis-stabilized telecommunications satellite platform).

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: According to Rocket Lab, DARPA’s Radio Frequency Risk Reduction Deployment Demonstration (R3D2) "intends to space-qualify a prototype reflect array antenna to improve radio communications in small spacecraft.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The maiden flight of OS-M1. The first orbital flight of OneSpace.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV14.

location: SLC-37B, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: A United Launch Alliance Delta 4 rocket will launch the 10th Wideband Global SATCOM spacecraft, formerly known as the Wideband Gapfiller Satellite. Built by Boeing, this geostationary communications spacecraft will serve U.S. military forces. The rocket will fly in the Medium+ (5,4) configuration with four solid rocket boosters.

Soyuz MS-12 is a Soyuz spaceflight which will transport three members of the Expedition 59 crew to the International Space Station. The members are NASA astronauts Nick Hague and Christina Hammock Koch along with Cosmonaut Alexey Ovchinin.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: ZX 6C (Zhongxing 6C, ChinaSat 6C) is a Chinese communications satellite based on a DFH-4 bus.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: The maiden orbital flight of Crew Dragon. It flew without crew as it is a test flight. Fastest droneship turnaround to date, at 8 days and 6 hours, nearly halving the previous record of 15 days and 23 hours.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS21.

location: VMS Eve, Mojave Air and Space Port, California, USA
details: First flight of SpaceShipTwo with a passenger. While the test flight was successful, post-flight inspections found a serious issue with the horizontal stabilizer that could have led to a catastrophic failure, according to the Washington Post.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Nusantara Satu (PSN 6) is a communications satellite for Pasifik Satelit Nusantara (PSN) of Indonesia. The spacecraft was built by SSL.

EgyptSat A (MisrSat A) is Egypt's third Earth remote-sounding satellite. The satellite is jointly built by Egypt's National Authority for Remote Sensing and Space Sciences together with RKK Energiya in Russia. The imaging payload was developed by OAO Peleng and NIRUP Geoinformatsionnye Sistemy in Belarus.

location: Safir Launch Pad, Semnan Space Center, Iran
details: Iran has not confirmed the status of the mission, but multiple reports claim that it failed.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA247, highest Ariane 5 ever launched.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: First flight of PSLV in the DL configuration.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: NS-10 was a test flight of New Shepard and a prototype Crew Capsule designed for space tourism. It carried 8 payloads for NASA's Flight Opportunities Program. Both vehicles were successfully recovered.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Jilin-1 satellites are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites for high-definition video. The Jilin-1 constellation is designed and owned by the Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co.

The KH-11 series, known as Kennen and Crystal, are American spy satellites utilizing electro-optical digital imaging for real-time observation, supplanting earlier film-return satellites. Manufactured by Lockheed, they likely incorporate a 2.4 m prime mirror, offering a theoretical 15 cm ground resolution. First launched by the American National Reconnaissance Office in December 1976, the KH-11 KENNEN was the inaugural American spy satellite to employ electro-optical digital imaging technology, enabling real-time optical observations.

location: Mu Pad, Uchinoura Space Center, Japan
details: The mission features seven technology demonstration payloads:

location: Imam Khomeini Spaceport, Semnan Space Center, Iran
details: The launch failed due to an anomaly with the rocket's third stage.

Ten Iridium NEXT satellites will help upgrade the Iridium Constellation. The launch is the last and final of the eight that Iridium has purchased from SpaceX and will complete the 75 satellite constellation. The Iridium satellite constellation provides L-band voice and data coverage to satellite phones, pagers and integrated transceivers over the entire Earth surface.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The ST 2 (Shen Tong 2) series satellites are reportedly Chinese military comsats and are follow-ups to the ST 1 series. They reportedly provide Ku-band communication and feature advanced multiple steerable spot beam antenna technology to enable ground users to communicate while on the move as well as secured uplink transmission for satellite antenna control.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Hongyan-1 is the first of several launches of a Chinese constellation of communications satellites built by CAST. This mission is expected to feature 1-2 test satellites.

Kanopus-V No. 5 and Kanopus-V No. 6 are two Russian remote sensing satellites which will join four others in the Kanopus-V constellation. The constellation is operated by the Russian Federal Space Agency, Roscosmos.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: TJS 3 (Tongxin Jishu Shiyan) is a Chinese geostationary satellite of unknown purpose.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: GPS III (Global Positioning System) is the first evolution of the third generation of GPS satellites. The U.S. Air Force announced in May 2008 that a team led by Lockheed Martin had won the competition to build the next-generation Global Positioning System (Navstar) Space System program, known as GPS III.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Hongyun-1 is a test satellite for the Hongyun constellation, a planned network of Chinese communications satellites built by the state-owned hi-tech company CASIC.
Orbit slightly too low, but as this will not impact the satellite's lifetime, the flight is considered a success.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS20.

location: Second Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: GSAT-7A is an advanced military communications satellite meant exclusively for the Indian Air Force. It is currently being developed in ISRO Satellite Centre. GSAT-7A is similar to Indian navy's GSAT-7 and the Indian Air Force will be the sole operator of the satellite. GSAT-7A will enable IAF to interlink different ground radar stations, ground airbase and Airborne early warning and control (AWACS) aircraft such as Beriev A-50 Phalcon and DRDO AEW&CS. The satellite will enhance Network-centric warfare capabilities of the Indian Air Force and therefore enhance its global operations.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The Educational Launch of Nanosatellites (ELaNa) is a NASA program to promote "access to space for small satellites, CubeSats, developed by the NASA Centers and programs, educational institutions and non-profit organizations giving CubeSat developers access to a low-cost pathway to conduct research in the areas of science, exploration, technology development, education or operations."

location: VMS Eve, Mojave Air and Space Port, California, USA
details: First SpaceShipTwo flight to reach space, with an apogee of 82.7 km. Although it fell short of the internationally recognized Kármán line (100 km), it reached the US definition of space (80 km).

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First space probe to land on the far side of the Moon.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: SaudiSat 5A and 5B are two Saudi-Arabian earth observation and technology demonstration satellites developed by the KACST (King Abdulaziz City for Science & Technology).

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: One of the four grid fins on the 1st stage of the Falcon 9 failed. As a result the booster was unable to land at Landing Zone 1, instead, it landed in the sea off of the coast of Florida. It was taken back to shore and scrapped.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA246.
B1046 became the first Falcon 9 first stage to fly three times. The boat Mr. Steven was not successful during an experimental fairing recovery attempt.

NASA astronaut Anne McClain, Canadian Space Agency astronaut David Saint-Jacques and Oleg Kononenko of the Russian space agency Roscosmos launch to the International Space Station aboard the Russian Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.
The Strela (Russian: Стрела) are Soviet, then Russian, military space telecommunication satellites, in use since 1964.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: The Hyperspectral Imaging Satellite (HySIS) is a payload by built by the Indian space agency ISRO. It is an Earth observation satellite.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV13.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Shiyan 6 (SY 6, Experiment 6) is an experimental Chinese satellite reportedly for studying the space environment.

details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. It carries Ka x Ku multi-beam and optical communication payloads for the first time. The mission targets Village Resource Centres (VRC) in rural areas to bridge the digital divide.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The first operational launch of the Electron rocket.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France

GLONASS-M (Russian: ГЛОНАСС-М), also known as Uragan-M (Russian: Ураган-М) are the second generation of Uragan satellite design used as part of the Russian GLONASS radio-based satellite navigation system.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. The missions of Ibuki 2 are to continue and enhance spaceborne measurement of major greenhouse gases from space started by GOSAT, to monitor the impacts of climate change and human activities on the carbon cycle, and to contribute to climate science and climate change related policies.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China

The mission is conducted by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) and the French CNES.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: First flight of Zhuque-1 and the maiden mission for Landspace. The first Chinese fully private launch.
Return to flight of Soyuz following the launch failure during the Soyuz MS-10 mission.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China

As of September 2018, four satellites were launched and four more are planned. The HaiYang series is operated by NSOAS (National Satellite Ocean Application Service), a subordinate agency of the State Oceanic Administration.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA245. First European mission to Mercury.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) is a series of communications satellites operated by the United States Air Force Space Command. They will be used to relay secure communications for the Armed Forces of the United States, the British Armed Forces, the Canadian Forces and the Royal Netherlands Armed Forces.

details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. The H-II Transfer Vehicle (HTV), also called Kounotori (こうのとり, Kōnotori, "Oriental stork" or "white stork"), is an expendable, automated cargo spacecraft used to resupply the Kibō Japanese Experiment Module (JEM) and the International Space Station (ISS). The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) has been working on the design since the early 1990s.

details: Telstar 18V (Telstar 18 Vantage / APStar 5C) is a communication satellite in the Telstar series of the Canadian satellite communications company Telesat. T18V will be equipped with C and Ku-band transponders and operate from 138° East.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: HaiYang (Chinese: "ocean"), abbreviated HY, is a marine remote sensing satellite series planned by China. The 442 kg box-shaped satellite is three-axis-stabilized and Earth-oriented, with the twin solar wings oriented to the sun. It incorporates an integrated onboard operation management system and has a design life of five years. Its payloads include a 10-band ocean color scanner with a revisit period of 3 days and a 4-band CCD imager with a revisit period of 7 days.

details: Delta IV Heavy used a Star-48BV third stage during this launch.

details: Final flight of Ariane 5 ES. Flight VA244.

details: Mission 9 featured an intentional ignition of the escape motor shortly after separation of the New Shepard capsule. This was to verify that the crew would be able to escape at all points during the flight. The booster and capsule were both recovered successfully.

The Progress spacecraft will attempt a super fast-tracked rendezvous with the Station, docking to the ISS less than 4 hours (2.5 orbits) after launch - making it the fastest orbital rendezvous ever-attempted with the Station.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-2 (formerly known as COMPASS) is a constellation of navigation satellites. It is not an extension of the older BeiDou-1 but rather supersedes it outright. The new system will be a constellation of 35 satellites, which include 5 geostationary orbit satellites for backward compatibility with BeiDou-1, and 30 non-geostationary satellites (27 in medium Earth orbit and 3 in inclined geosynchronous orbit), that will offer complete coverage of the globe.

GLONASS-M, also known as Uragan-M are the second generation of Uragan satellite design used as part of the Russian GLONASS radio-based satellite navigation system.

The IGS-Radar 3 and 4 (Intelligence Gathering Satellite), are the second generation of Japanese radar reconnaissance satellites. The satellite are operated by the Cabinet Satellite Information Center. The satellite serves both Japan's national defense and civil natural disaster monitoring.
Soyuz MS-09 is a Soyuz spaceflight which transported three members of the Expedition 56 crew to the International Space Station.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: China's geostationary meteorological satellite program FY-2 (Feng Yun 2) began its development in 1980. It is built by the Shanghai Institute of Satellite Engineering.

details: Gaofen (GF) is a series of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites for the state-sponsored program China High-definition Earth Observation System (CHEOS).

details: First Chinese mission to the Lagrange L2 point.

details: Gaofen (GF) is a series of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites for the state-sponsored program China High-definition Earth Observation System (CHEOS).

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Apstar 6C is a Chinese communications satellite that is operated by APT Satellite Holdings as part of the Apstar system.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: New Shepard flew again for the eighth time from Blue Origin’s West Texas Launch Site. The mission featured a reflight of the vehicle flown on Mission 7. The Crew Capsule reached an apogee of 351,000 feet (66 miles, 107 kilometers) – the altitude being targeted for operations.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The OVS 2 earth observation satellites, also called Zhuhai-1, are the video component of the Chinese Orbita or Zhuhai-1 earth observation system by Zhuhai Orbita Control Engineering Ltd.

Sentinel-3B is an Earth observation satellite constellation developed by the European Space Agency as part of the Copernicus Programme.
Copernicus, formerly Global Monitoring for Environment and Security, is the European programme to establish a European capacity for Earth observation designed to provide European policymakers and public authorities with accurate and timely information to better manage the environment and to understand and mitigate the effects of climate change.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Last flight of a new Falcon 9 Block 4 first stage.
Blagovest is a series of four planned communications satellites for russian domestic services.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: CBAS (Continuous Broadcast Augmenting SATCOM) is a geostationary satellite to provide communications relay capabilities to support senior leaders, combatant commanders, augmenting existing military satcom.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: IRNSS-1I is the eighth operational satellite in the Indian Regional Navigational Satellite System (IRNSS) series of satellites.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Yaogan-31 satellites are Chinese military satellites, launched in triplets, similar to the American NOSS system. They are equipped with two solar panels each. This constellation is used for ELINT (Electronic Intelligence). The Yaogan-31 satellites are also followed on their orbit by the Yaogan-34 observation satellites, used to confirm or complete the observation made by the Yaogan-31 triplet.

details: Flight VA242.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: SpaceX CRS-14, also known as SpX-14, was a Commercial Resupply Service mission to the International Space Station. Dragon was berthed to the station for 30 days before it successfully returned to Earth. 2,647kg of cargo were brought to the station, 1,721kg pressurized, 926kg unpressurized. This mission was flown by Dragon C110-2.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Gaofen (GF) is a series of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites for the state-sponsored program China High-definition Earth Observation System (CHEOS).
Ten Iridium Next satellites will help upgrade the Iridium Constellation. The launch is one of eight that Iridium has purchased from SpaceX. In total, 75 satellites will be launched.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. When fully completed, BeiDou will provide an alternative global navigation satellite system to the United States-owned Global Positioning System (GPS) and is expected to be more accurate than the GPS. It was claimed in 2016 that BeiDou-3 will reach millimeter-level accuracy (with post-processing), which is ten times more accurate than the finest level of GPS.
The russian Cosmos 2525, also called EMKA is a satellite of unknown purpose.

location: Second Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: GSAT-6A is a communications satellite operated by the Indian Space Research Organisation. It features a 6-metre (20 ft) unfurlable S-band antenna similar to the one used on GSAT-6.
Soyuz MS-08 is a Soyuz spaceflight that transported three members of the Expedition 55 crew to the International Space Station.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The LKW (Ludikancha Weixing, Land Surveying Satellite) is a Chinese very high resolution earth observation satellite.

location: ELS, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VS18.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The 50th launch of the Falcon 9.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: GOES-17 (formerly GOES-S) is the second of the current generation of weather satellites operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The four satellites of the series (GOES-16, -17, -T, and -U) will extend the availability of the GOES (Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite system) until 2036 for weather forecast and meteorology research. The satellite was built by Lockheed Martin, was based on the A2100A platform, and will have an expected useful life of 15 years (10 years operational after five years of standby as an on-orbit replacement).

The IGS-Optical 6 (Intelligence Gathering Satellite) is the first of the third generation Japanese optical reconnaissance satellite. The satellites are operated by the Cabinet Satellite Information Center. The satellite serves both Japan's national defense and civil natural disaster monitoring.

The first launch to feature Fairing 2.0 – an upgraded fairing designed for reusability. It was also the first launch to feature a fairing recovery attempt using the vessel Mr. Steven. The attempt was unsuccessful. Final flight of Falcon 9 Block 3.
Progress MS-08 is a Soviet/Russian Progress cargo vehicle which docked to the ISS. It's the 160th Progress flight.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. When fully completed, BeiDou will provide an alternative global navigation satellite system to the United States-owned Global Positioning System (GPS) and is expected to be more accurate than the GPS. It was claimed in 2016 that BeiDou-3 will reach millimeter-level accuracy (with post-processing), which is ten times more accurate than the finest level of GPS.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: Maiden flight of the Falcon Heavy. The primary mission was a complete success. Additionally, both side boosters successfully performed experimental landings. The center core failed an experimental landing attempt.

location: Lambda Pad, Uchinoura Space Center, Japan
details: SS-520 became the smallest active rocket to successfully launch a satellite.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: CSES (China Seismo-Electromagnetic Satellite) is a Chinese–Italian space mission dedicated to monitoring the electromagnetic field and waves, plasma parameters, and particle fluxes induced by natural sources and artificial emitters in near-Earth space. Austria contributes to one of the magnetometers.

Kanopus-V (Kanopus-Vulkan) is a compact Russian remote sensing satellite designed to provide operational weather information for various tasks, including monitoring man-made and natural emergencies, mapping, detecting forest fires and environmental pollutants, registering abnormal physical phenomena for earthquake prediction, and monitoring agriculture, water, coastal resources, and land use. Developed by NPO VNII Elektromekhaniki, with avionics subcontracted to SSTL and the imager built by OAO Peleng, Kanopus-V serves the Ministry of the Russian Federation for Civil Defense, Emergencies and Elimination of Consequences of Natural Disasters, Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation, the Federal Service for Hydrometeorology and Environmental Monitoring, and the Russian Academy of Sciences.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: Designed exclusively to address governmental and institutional security user needs, GovSat-1 is the first satellite of GovSat, a public-private partnership between the Government of Luxembourg and the satellite operator SES.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Due to programming errors in the Guidance, Navigation, and Control (GNC), the satellites were placed on an off-nominal orbit. Flight VA241.

location: LC-3, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The Yaogan 30-xx (Remote Sensing Satellite-30-xx) satellites, were launched by CZ-2C (3) rocket from China's Xichang space center. The purpose is not confirmed, although the news reports hint towards a SIGINT mission, especially to detect ships by their radio emissions. They are also known as CX 5 by the manufacturer.

location: Rocket Lab LC-1A, Māhia Peninsula, New Zealand
details: The first successful launch of the Electron rocket. First flight of the Curie stage.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The Space-Based Infrared System (SBIRS) is a consolidated system intended to meet the United States' infrared space surveillance needs through the first two to three decades of the 21st century. The SBIRS program is designed to provide key capabilities in the areas of missile warning, missile defense and battlespace characterization via satellites in geosynchronous earth orbit (GEO), sensors hosted on satellites in highly elliptical orbit (HEO), and ground-based data processing and control. SBIRS ground software integrates infrared sensor programs of the U.S. Air Force (USAF) with new IR sensors.

location: Site 95A, Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Jilin 1 satellites are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites for high-definition video within the Jilin-1 constellation designed and owned by the Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co.

location: Mu Pad, Uchinoura Space Center, Japan
details: First flight of the PBS stage.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The LKW (Ludikancha Weixing, Land Surveying Satellite) is a Chinese very high resolution earth observation satellite.
Final flight of Delta IV M+(5,2) variant.

location: First Launch Pad, Satish Dhawan Space Centre, India
details: Cartosat-2 carries a state-of-the-art panchromatic (PAN) camera that take black and white pictures of the earth in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The swath covered by this high resolution PAN camera is 9.6 km and their spatial resolution is less than 1 metre. The satellite can be steered up to 45 degrees along as well as across the track.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: GaoJing-1, also known as SuperView-1 is a constellation of Chinese civilian remote sensing satellites operated by Beijing Space View Tech Co Ltd.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The classified Zuma satellite is believed to have failed to separate from the top of the Falcon 9's second stage after launch. Therefore, the billion dollar payload reentered the Earth's atmosphere shortly after launch. The failure has been linked with a Northrop Grumman built payload adapter, and thus the Falcon 9 performed properly and the launch is a success.
Last flight of Zenit from the Baikonur cosmodrome.

GCOM-C (Global Change Observation Mission – Climate "Shikisai"), the first satellite in the GCOM-C series, will monitor global climate change by observing the surface and atmosphere of Earth over the course of 5 years. Through use of its SGLI (Second generation Global Imager) optical instrument, it will collect data related to the carbon cycle and radiation budget, such as measurements of clouds, aerosols, ocean color, vegetation, and snow and ice.
Soyuz MS-07 transported three members of the Expedition 54 crew to the International Space Station.

location: SLC-40, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The first Falcon 9 mission from SLC-40 after the AMOS-6 anomaly caused heavy damage to the pad. First mission to feature both a flight-proven Booster and Dragon Capsule.

location: ELA-3, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VA240.

location: Launch Site One, West Texas, Texas, USA
details: First flight of NS3.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: Alcomsat-1 is the first Algerian communication satellite. The satellite is designed for a 15-year operational lifetime and is a partnership between Algerian Space Agency (ASAL) and China. It is dedicated to telecommunications, television broadcasting, and internet services.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The LKW (Ludikancha Weixing, Land Surveying Satellite) is a Chinese very high-resolution earth observation satellite.

details: Jilin 1 satellites are a series of Chinese commercial remote sensing satellites for high-definition video within the Jilin-1 constellation designed and owned by the Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co.

NOAA-20, designated JPSS-1 prior to launch, is the first of the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's latest generation of U.S. polar-orbiting, non-geosynchronous, environmental satellites called the Joint Polar Satellite System.

location: LC-9, Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: The newer FY-3 series is an improved generation of polar-orbiting heliosynchronous weather satellites.

location: LP-0A, Wallops Flight Facility, Virginia, USA
details: Cygnus OA-8E (Orbital ATK-8E) is a cargo resupply mission of the Orbital ATK Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station under the Commercial Resupply Services (CRS) contract with NASA.

location: ELV, Guiana Space Centre, French Guiana, France
details: Flight VV11.

location: LC-2, Xichang Satellite Launch Center, China
details: BeiDou-3 will eventually consist of 35 satellites and is expected to provide global services upon completion in 2020. When fully completed, BeiDou will provide an alternative global navigation satellite system to the United States-owned Global Positioning System (GPS), and is expected to be more accurate than the GPS. It was claimed in 2016 that BeiDou-3 will reach millimeter-level accuracy (with post-processing), which is ten times more accurate than the finest level of GPS.

SkySat-3 to 21 (SkySat C1 to C19) are commercial Earth observation satellites by Skybox Imaging, licensed to collect high resolution panchromatic and multispectral images of the earth. The satellites operate in a polar inclined, circular orbit at approximately 450 km above the earth.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: Manufactured by Thales Alenia Space and located at 113°E, Koreasat-5A will provide Direct-to-Home (DTH) broadcast, broadband, and backhaul services with its Ku-Band capacity. Koreasat5A provides KT SAT with 12 Ku-band transponders of 36MHz, and 24 Ku-band transponders of 54MHz.

location: SLC-41, Cape Canaveral SFS, Florida, USA
details: The fourth generation of Quasar satellites, also known as SDS-4, represents the latest evolution in the Satellite Data System (SDS) developed by the United States Air Force. Building upon the capabilities of previous generations, SDS-4 continues to serve as a critical communication relay for real-time data from US reconnaissance satellites and supports communication needs for USAF aircraft and ground stations. While specific details about SDS-4 remain classified, it likely incorporates state-of-the-art technology advancements to further improve data transmission rates, communication reliability, and overall performance.
Progress MS-07 is a Soviet/Russian Progress cargo vehicle which docked to the ISS. It's the 159th Progress flight.

Sentinel-5 Precursor (Sentinel-5P) is an Earth observation satellite developed by ESA as part of the Copernicus Programme to close the gap in continuity of observations between Envisat and Sentinel-5.

location: LC-39A, Kennedy Space Center, Florida, USA
details: EchoStar 105/SES-11, a high-powered hybrid Ku and C-band communications satellite, is a dual-mission satellite for US-based operator EchoStar and Luxembourg-based operator SES. EchoStar 105/SES-11 provides EchoStar with 24 Ku-band transponders of 36 MHz, marketed as EchoStar 105, while it provides SES with a C-band payload of 24 transponders, marketed under the name SES-11.

QZSS (Quasi Zenith Satellite System) is a Japanese satellite navigation system operating from inclined, elliptical geosynchronous orbits to achieve optimal high-elevation visibility in urban canyons and mountainous areas, as well as from geostationary orbits. The navigation system objective is to broadcast GPS-interoperable and augmentation signals as well as original Japanese (QZSS) signals from a three-spacecraft constellation.
Ten Iridium Next satellites will help upgrade the Iridium Constellation. The launch is one of eight that Iridium has purchased from SpaceX. In total, 75 satellites will be launched.

location: Site 9401 (SLS-2), Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, China
details: VRSS-2 or Antonio José de Sucre is Venezuela's second remote sensing satellite.

details: Flight VA239.
